abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Transport Project for
            Kingston, Jamaica achieved an overall satisfactory outcome.
            Project objectives were met but complications arose
            concerning sustainability of results due to the massive
            devaluation of the Jamaican dollar and the government's
            increased expenditure on maintenance. There were some
            positive achievements in the institutional strengthening of
            the Ministry of Construction (Works) specifically with
            respect to staffing, streamlining of project training,
            traffic management, and some civil works. But success was
            uneven because of the borrower's focus on maintenance
            works and equipment purchase with traffic management
            measures often delayed or ultimately scrapped. The project
            experienced a number of significant delays. One of the main
            reasons for this was the lack of counterpart funding.
            Because some of the Bank's project components were seen
            as less important than those of other externally funded
            projects, they were deferred for lack of sufficient funds.
            Generally the bank performed well throughout the project
            cycle, providing a high level of input during the critical
            implementation stages and keeping staff changes to a
            minimum. The Borrower also performed well generally during
            project implementation, particularly with respect to civil
            works. The main issue of adequate and timely provision of
            counterpart funds was out of the Ministry's control.
            There were three key lessons learned. First, a sectoral
            perspective in transport is essential to avoid distortions
            within the sector and ensure an appropriate level of
            government budgetary support. Second, a strong and
            responsive implementing/executing agency as well as strong
            sectoral coordination among external financiers is very
            important in realizing project success as is the Bank's
            commitment to the sector. Third, simplicity in focus as well
            as design reduces the need for complex coordination, and
            allows the Bank and Borrower to more easily monitor implementation.

Jamaica - Kingston Urban Transport Project :
            Loan 2389 - Loan Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Jamaica - Kingston Urban
            Transport Project : Loan 2389 - Loan Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal objective of the Kingston
            Metropolitan Urban Transport Project is to promote the
            development of an adequate and efficient urban transport
            system in the of the Kingston Metropolitan Region (KMR),
            following the divestment of the publicly-owned Jamaica
            Omnibus Company to the private sector. The project is
            designed to minimize the annual foreign exchange
            requirements for the operation of vehicles in the KMR and to
            rationalize and reduce in real terms Government expenditures
            in the urban transport sector. The project comprises the
            following major components: (i) traffic management measures,
            including steps for improving traffic flow along the three
            most heavily travelled public transport corridors in the
            KMR, intersection improvements, and traffic signals; (ii)
            support for the 7 1/2-year road maintenance program in the
            KMR; and (iii) technical assistance and training to assist
            in the execution of the project and to improve management of
            the KMR urban transport system.
